title: Getting Started
text: Example data original paper included package. ’ll use demonstration. data called lord_jcb. basic SuperPlot can generated following code:  generate SuperPlot Speed data, Treatment x-axis Replicate used group data. y-axis label set “Speed”. equivalent call long form :
code: library(SuperPlotR) superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") superplot(   df = lord_jcb,   meas = "Speed",   cond = "Treatment",   repl = "Replicate",   ylab = "Speed (µm/min)" )

title: Getting Started
text: separate vignete describes customise sizing plot. look major customisations.

title: Getting Started
text: underlying data can rendered violins,  jittered scatter plot, default (shown first example page) uses sina jittered scatter plot density estimate.
code: superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", datadist = "violin") superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", datadist = "jitter")

title: Getting Started
text: colours points can changed. default Paul Tol’s bright palette ("tol_bright") can select : “tol_bright” “tol_vibrant” “tol_muted” “tol_light” Color Universal Design (“cud”)  ’s possible supply palette vector colours (hex description format)
code: superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", pal = "cud") superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", pal = c("#ff0000", "blue", "green"))

title: Getting Started
text: mean replicate shown default. can also show median

title: Getting Started
text: default SuperPlot include bars indicate mean ± error. can added using bars argument. Options : “mean_sd” = mean ± standard deviation “mean_sem” = mean ± standard error mean “mean_ci” = mean ± 95% confidence interval Note bars show mean ± error replicate means underlying data points.

title: Getting Started
text: default, data points circles. want use different shapes different conditions, can use shapes argument. Set TRUE use different shapes replicate.  ’d like link summary points, set linking = TRUE.
code: superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", shapes = TRUE) superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", linking = TRUE)

title: Getting Started
text: SuperPlot can saved PDF PNG file using ggsave function ggplot2 package.
code: library(ggplot2) p <- superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",                ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") ggsave("superplot.pdf", p) #> Saving 6 x 4 in image

title: Getting Started
text: separate vignette describes customise SuperPlot . See vignette("going-deeper").

title: Going Deeper
text: vignette, explore advanced features SuperPlotR. first, need deal simply scale plot looks good paper!

title: Going Deeper
text: default setting use point sizes 2 data 3 summary points. font size 12. looks good RStudio viewer, well suited figure likely small.   look great viewer, look better figure.
code: library(SuperPlotR) # the default plot superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") # the same plot but with custom sizing superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)",           size = c(0.8,1.5), fsize = 9) library(ggplot2) # the same plot but with custom sizing superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",                ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", size = c(0.8,1.5), fsize = 9) ggsave("plot.pdf", width = 88, height = 50, units = "mm")

title: Going Deeper
text: couple simple tweaks: x label can added transparency points can altered like .  SuperPlotR returns ggplot object can customised like. example, theme can overridden like :  can also accept ggplot object add SuperPlot (within reason!). example, might want plot things behind data points.
code: superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           xlab = "Drug", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", alpha = c(0.3,1)) p <- superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") p + theme_minimal() p <- ggplot() +   geom_hline(yintercept = 20, linetype = "dashed", col = "grey") superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", gg = p)

title: Going Deeper
text: Facetting partially supported. simple scenario facetting replicate, can :  another variable wished facet , possible limitation. summary points facet, may want.  best way correct summary points make two superplots filtering data B, combine using patchwork similar package.
code: p <- superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") p + facet_wrap(~Replicate) df <- cbind(lord_jcb, other = rep(c("A", "B"), 150)) p <- superplot(df, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") p + facet_wrap(~other)

title: Going Deeper
text: best done reordering levels factor input dataframe calling superplot.
code: df <- lord_jcb df$Treatment <- factor(df$Treatment, levels = c("Drug", "Control")) superplot(df, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)")

title: Making SuperPlots in R
text: goal SuperPlotR allow user easily generate SuperPlots R. SuperPlots way visualise data way emphasises experimental reproducibility. can read SuperPlots original paper: Lord et al. (2020) SuperPlots: Communicating reproducibility variability cell biology. J. Cell Biol. 219(6):e202001064

title: Making SuperPlots in R
text: can install development version SuperPlotR GitHub :

title: Making SuperPlots in R
text: simple example use SuperPlotR shown :  data used example included package original paper. generate SuperPlot, need data frame least three columns. columns : variable measured experiment, experimental condition, experimental repeat measurment comes . superplot function takes data frame, names three columns, customisable additional arguments. See vignette("getting-started") examples, vignette("going-deeper") advanced usage.

title: Making SuperPlots in R
text: SuperPlot package IGOR Pro available popular web-based app generating SuperPlots, developed Joachim Goedhart available

Get shapes for data and summary plots — get_sp_shapes
text: n number shapes return shape_logical logical whether use different shapes replicates. Default FALSE, results circle used. TRUE means selection shapes used, data summary points replicate . Four shapes possible, n greater 4, shapes repeat (different colors).

title: Make a SuperPlot — superplot
text: Make SuperPlot

title: Make a SuperPlot — superplot
code: superplot(   df,   meas,   cond,   repl,   pal = "tol_bright",   xlab = "",   ylab = "Measurement",   datadist = "sina",   size = c(2, 3),   alpha = c(0.5, 0.7),   bars = "",   linking = FALSE,   rep_summary = "rep_mean",   shapes = FALSE,   fsize = 12,   gg = NULL )

title: Make a SuperPlot — superplot
text: df data frame least three columns: meas, cond, repl meas character name column measurement (e.g. intensity) cond character name column condition (e.g. Control, WT) repl character name column replicate (e.g. unique experiment identifiers) pal name colour palette use (default "tol_bright") xlab string x label (default empty) ylab string y label (default "Measurement") datadist string data distribution use, select ("sina" default, "jitter", "violin") size numeric vector size range data summary points (default c(0.8, 1.5)) alpha numeric vector alpha range data summary points (default c(0.5, 0.7)) bars string type error bars add, select ("none" default, "mean_sd", "mean_sem", "mean_ci") linking logical whether link summary points conditions (default FALSE) rep_summary string summary statistic use replicates, select ("rep_mean" default, "rep_median") shapes logical whether use different shapes replicates fsize numeric font size text (default 9) gg ggplot object add (default NULL)

title: Make a SuperPlot — superplot
text: ggplot object
